DOCNAME: CASE OF WITOLD LITWA v. POLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 5-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , born in DATE , is disabled in that he is blind in CARDINAL eye and his sight in the other is severely impaired .

CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME the applicant , with the dog he uses as a guide dog , went to ORG no . CARDINAL to check his post - office boxes . He was accompanied by PERSON The applicant 's post - office boxes had been opened and were empty . The applicant complained to the post - office clerks who subsequently called the police , alleging that the applicant was drunk and behaving offensively .

CARDINAL . On DATE , at TIME , the applicant was taken by police officers to the PERSON sobering - up centre ( PERSON ) and detained there for TIME . The staff of the centre filled out a form recording the applicant 's stay .

CARDINAL . The form was pre - printed . It bore the number CARDINAL/CARDINAL and was entitled “ Card recording a stay in a sobering - up centre ” . It had been filled out by hand . After details of the applicant 's identity , the form was divided into CARDINAL sections . The first section , entitled “ Request for admission ” , indicated that the applicant had arrived at the centre at TIME The reason for the arrest was partly typed and partly handwritten . The operative part of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the PERSON of DATE ( cited below in paragraph CARDINAL ) was typed in . The handwritten note read :
“ [ The applicant ] made a row at the post office in GPE . ”
CARDINAL . The second section , entitled “ Doctor 's assessment ” and signed by a doctor , read :
“ CARDINAL . Anamnesis :
( CARDINAL ) Circumstances , kind and quantity of alcohol drunk , facts surrounding intoxication : [ handwriting ] evident smell of alcohol DATE refused to take a breath test
CARDINAL . Examination of the person brought in :
( CARDINAL ) Behaviour : lucid ; unconscious ; somnolent ; talkative ; calm ; rowdy ; reticent ; composed [ the words “ lucid ” and “ talkative ” were underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Mood : cheerful ; depressed , average ; excited [ the word “ average ” was underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Walk : steady ; unsteady ; lack of balance [ the word “ unsteady ” was underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Speech : clear ; blurred ; mumbling [ the word “ blurred ” was underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Traces of vomit : visible ; invisible [ the word “ invisible ” was underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Pulse : regular ; irregular ; strong ; weak [ the words “ regular ” and “ strong ” were underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Heart : regular beat ; irregular beat ; clear tones ; unclear [ the words “ regular beat ” and “ clear tones ” were underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL) Pupils : wide ; normal ; abnormal ; narrow ; slow to react ; no reaction [ the word “ normal ” was underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Skin : pale ; red ; normal supply of blood ; blue [ the words “ normal supply of blood ” were underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) Lungs : [ illegible handwriting ]
( CARDINAL ) State of abdominal cavity : [ handwriting ] abdomen [ illegible adjective ]
( CARDINAL ) Injuries : [ handwriting ] none
( CARDINAL ) Other ailments : [ handwriting ] sight seriously impaired
( CARDINAL ) Description of the state of the person examined : [ handwriting ] state of moderate intoxication
[ Print ] As a result of the examination I find that the person brought in :
( CARDINAL ) is in a state of intoxication justifying keeping him in a sobering - up centre for [ handwriting ] CARDINAL [ print ] TIME [ that entry was underlined by hand ]
( CARDINAL ) should be taken to a public health - care establishment [ not selected ]
( CARDINAL ) should not be placed in a sobering - up centre [ not selected ] ”

CARDINAL . The subsequent sections were entitled “ III . Decision of the head of the centre / shift ” and “ IV . Objects to be kept in the centre 's custody ” . This section listed the objects taken from the applicant as follows :

“ ... identity card [ no . ] DB CARDINAL ; [ illegible description of other documents ] ; CARDINAL [ old ] MONEY ( PLZ ) ; ORG watch [ made of ] golden metal ; tear - gas gun ; [ illegible description of other items ] ; keys ( CARDINAL ) ; purse ; jacket ; shirt ; trousers ; belt ; shoes . ”

CARDINAL . Section V , entitled “ Alcohol taken from [ the person concerned ] ” , contained no entry . Section VI , entitled “ Stay in the sobering - up centre ” , contained a list of the measures which could be applied to an intoxicated person ( they included administering medicines , a warm or cold bath , solitary confinement , physical restraint by means of belts or a strait - jacket ) and a description of his behaviour . The applicant 's behaviour , mental and physical state were assessed as “ good ” . The last section , “ VII . Release from the sobering - up centre ” , recorded that after TIME the applicant had been assessed by the doctor as “ sober ” and released at TIME A handwritten note indicated that the applicant had refused to sign the card .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested ORG ) to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers who had arrested him on DATE and against the staff of the PERSON sobering - up centre . He alleged that the policemen had beaten him and complained about the behaviour of the staff of the centre .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sued the ORG in ORG ( Sąd Wojewódzki ) , seeking compensation “ for unlawful attacks by agents of the ORG on CARDINAL DATE and theft of personal possessions ” . The court considered that the applicant 's claim should be examined as a claim for compensation for manifestly unjustified arrest , under LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the claim , finding that the applicant 's arrest had been justified . That decision reads as follows :

“ On the basis of [ the applicant 's ] testimony , written information from ORG and the [ materials ] contained in file no . CARDINAL DS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of ORG , that is , the detention form ... no . CARDINAL containing the request for admission , we find that on DATE [ the applicant ] , being under the influence of alcohol , caused a disturbance of public order [ zakłócił porządek publiczny ] in ORG no . CARDINAL ... in GPE . The police intervened at the request of the postal clerks . Since the arrestee smelt of alcohol , he was taken to the sobering - up centre , where , following a medical examination , he was assessed as being ' moderately intoxicated ' and admitted .
The above facts indicate that [ the applicant 's ] arrest was justified . There is therefore no basis for awarding him compensation under the provisions of LAW of LAW . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE FAC , on suspicion that offences of assault , theft and infringement of the applicant 's personal rights had been committed , opened an investigation relating to the applicant 's complaint of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the decision of ORG of DATE . He argued that this decision was not based on any sound evidence , but only on the statements of the policemen . He further stated that he had been assaulted by the policemen and that his personal belongings had been stolen . The applicant relied on Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL § DATE and CARDINAL of the Convention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Sąd Apelacyjny ) dismissed the appeal . The reasons for its decision read :

“ The [ applicant 's ] appeal is not justified . Contrary to his submissions , on the material date , that is , on DATE [ the applicant ] was under the influence of alcohol ; his state was described as ' moderate intoxication ' . While in that state , he went to ORG no . DATE , where he disturbed public order . Employees at that office called the police ... [ T]he policemen , finding that the applicant smelt of alcohol , took him to the sobering - up centre . As a result of the [ medical ] examination it was found that he was in a state of ' moderate intoxication ' and detained until he sobered up . The applicant refused to take a breath test .

The [ applicant 's belongings ] were taken from him in the presence of the policemen and placed in the centre 's custody . ... In that connection it must be said that the policemen did not rob the applicant . The policemen 's intervention and the placing of the applicant in the sobering - up centre were justified .
[ We ] can not therefore share [ the applicant 's ] view that the policemen committed robbery and that the applicant was arrested and placed in the sobering - up centre groundlessly . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE FAC discontinued the investigation opened at the applicant 's request . However , on DATE ORG ( Prokurator Wojewódzki ) , upon the applicant 's appeal , quashed this decision and ordered a supplementary investigation .
CARDINAL . On DATE a policeman from the ORG police heard evidence from PERSON , who had witnessed the events of CARDINAL DATE at the post office . The relevant part of the latter 's testimony read :

“ I have known [ the applicant ] since DATE but we do not have regular contact and do not meet frequently . DATE , on a date which I can not [ now ] specify , I met [ the applicant ] in PERSON [ a district of GPE ] . We went together to an optician and , then , to the post office . He did not tell me why he was going to the post office . He had his dog with him and , since no dogs were permitted to enter the office , I remained outside the building , holding the dog on the leash [ at the applicant 's request ] . [ The applicant ] went into the building . After some time he came back , in a state of agitation , and said that either his post - office boxes had not been locked [ by the postal clerks ] or someone had broken into them . He immediately went back into the office . Out of curiosity , I followed him with the dog . Immediately afterwards , CARDINAL policemen entered the building and approached [ the applicant ] . He told me to get the dog out of the building . At the same time , CARDINAL of the policemen approached me and checked my identity card . I then left the building . When I was standing outside , I saw the policemen taking [ the applicant ] out of the building , escorting him to a patrol car and leaving . In my view , [ the applicant ] remained calm throughout this incident ; therefore , I do not know why he was taken away by the policemen . I did not see the policemen hitting him while escorting him ; they were holding him with their hands . I can not recall whether or not [ the applicant ] told the policemen that the dog I was holding on the leash was his ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG police discontinued the investigation , finding that no offence had been committed . The relevant parts of the reasons for the decision read :

“ Accordingly , evidence was heard from the policemen [ involved in the incident of CARDINAL DATE ] . They stated that [ the applicant ] had been brought to the [ PERSON ] sobering - up centre in connection with a row made by him and his state of intoxication . They did not hit him ; they merely kept hold of him while taking him to a patrol car and putting him inside . They stated that [ the applicant ] had not had a dog with him and that , inside the post office , there was a man holding a dog [ on a leash ] , namely PERSON However , nobody knew that this dog belonged to [ the applicant ] . ... A doctor from the [ PERSON ] sobering - up centre confirmed that [ the applicant ] had been intoxicated ... ”
This decision was confirmed by FAC on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON , having been acquainted with the reasons for the above decision , made a statement before a notary . The relevant part of this statement read :

“ I , PERSON , hereby declare before a notary that , after being acquainted with [ the decision to discontinue the investigation ] , I disagree with the description [ given therein ] of events which I witnessed .

When evidence was taken from me , I entirely denied the insinuation that [ the applicant ] had been drunk ; ... I spent TIME with him prior to the incident and I [ still ] totally exclude such a possibility .

[ The applicant ] did not make a row at the post office ; he raised his voice merely in order to be heard above the clamour being made by a large number of clients ... CARDINAL persons queuing at the post office counters at the same time . ... He loudly demanded to speak to the postmaster in order to obtain an explanation of why his post - office boxes had been unlocked ... and [ why ] CARDINAL of these boxes had been broken . ... His dog remained outside because the building was overcrowded so the dog could not have been inside ... as the policemen claimed ; they [ simply ] lied . The postmaster did not come to see [ the applicant ] ; instead , the policemen appeared and demanded that we show them our identity cards . I gave them my card and [ the applicant ] , calmly , gave his . They checked the cards thoroughly and made notes in their notebooks . By checking [ the applicant 's ] documents they must have learnt that he was an invalid [ i.e. that his sight was severely impaired ] ... They gave me back my identity card but [ the applicant ] was taken to a patrol car and taken away . During his arrest [ the applicant ] behaved in a calm manner ; he only requested the policemen either to let him take his dog with him or to ensure [ that it would be taken by someone else ] . I witnessed this . They did not respond to his request and left ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE FAC reopened , ex officio , the investigation into the events of CARDINAL DATE but discontinued it on DATE , finding that no offence had been committed .

CARDINAL . The PERSON of DATE on ORG in GPE and the Fight against Alcoholism ( LOC o wychowaniu w trzeźwości i przeciwdziałaniu alkoholizmowi – “ the PERSON of DATE ” ) lays down measures which may be applied in respect of CARDINAL categories of persons : those “ addicted to alcohol ” and those who are “ intoxicated ” . Sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL deal with voluntary or compulsory treatment of “ persons addicted to alcohol ” , whereas sections DATE and CARDINAL set out measures which may be applied to “ intoxicated persons ” .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the PERSON , sobering - up centres shall be set up and managed by the authorities of municipalities with CARDINAL inhabitants .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Law ( in the version applicable at the material time ) provided , in its relevant part :

“ CARDINAL . Intoxicated persons who behave offensively in a public place or a place of employment , are in a condition endangering their life or health , or are themselves endangering other persons ' life or health , may be taken to a sobering - up centre or a public health - care establishment , or to their place of residence .
CARDINAL . NORP In the absence of a sobering - up centre , such persons may be taken to a [ police station ] .
CARDINAL . [ Intoxicated ] persons who have been taken to a sobering - up centre or a [ police station ] shall remain there until they are sober but for no longer than TIME ...

CARDINAL . Where it is justified to institute proceedings [ in respect of an intoxicated person ] with a view to [ his undergoing ] compulsory treatment [ for addiction to alcohol ] , [ the authorities concerned ] shall immediately report [ this fact ] to the relevant committee for fighting alcoholism ... ”

CARDINAL . A person arrested and subsequently confined in a sobering - up centre under section CARDINAL of the PERSON is not entitled to bring proceedings challenging the lawfulness of the deprivation of his liberty since , according to LAW , only a person arrested on suspicion of having committed an offence may appeal against a decision to arrest him ( see ORG judgment ( no . I ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) of CARDINAL DATE reached by a bench of CARDINAL judges , OSNKW CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The Ordinance of ORG CARDINAL DATE on taking intoxicated persons to sobering - up centres , the organisation of those centres , the medical care provided by them and the fees for transportation to and staying in soberingup centres or police stations ( repealed by an Ordinance of the Minister of ORG of DATE ) set out detailed rules relating to detention in a sobering - up centre .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Ordinance ( in the version applicable at the material time ) provided :
“ CARDINAL . A person taken to a sobering - up centre shall promptly be given a medical examination .

CARDINAL . Following the medical examination , a doctor shall ascertain whether such person should be placed in a sobering - up centre ... , or should be placed in a hospital or other medical establishment ... , or whether there are no signs of intoxication justifying a placement in a sobering - up centre . ”

CARDINAL . No provision obliged the authorities to carry out in addition any tests ( such as blood or breath tests ) to establish whether or not a given person was intoxicated . The relevant part of LAW provided :
“ An alcohol - level test shall be carried out at the request of the intoxicated person ... ”

CARDINAL . According to LAW , a person placed in a sobering - up centre was to be charged for both lodging and transportation there , at rates estimated to amount to , respectively , PERCENT of an average DATE salary in the public sector . If the person concerned did not have sufficient money , a sobering - up centre was entitled , under LAW , to take a lien over his possessions .

CARDINAL . Disturbance of public order ( zakłócenie porządku publicznego ) was at the material time a minor offence punishable under LAW . That Article , in the version applicable at the material time , provided :

“ CARDINAL . Anyone who , by shouting or by noisy , alarming or other unruly behaviour disturbs the public peace or the public order , or a [ citizen 's ] TIME rest or who behaves offensively in a public place , shall be liable to a maximum of DATE imprisonment or a fine of [ between PLZ CARDINAL,CARDINAL and ] CARDINAL ...
CARDINAL . NORP If the behaviour in question is of a hooligan nature or the person concerned was intoxicated , he shall be liable to [ a maximum of DATE ] imprisonment ... or a fine [ of MONEY ] . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted LAW . The text of the draft provision of the future DATE was contained in LAW as follows :
“ In this Convention , the Member GPE shall undertake to ensure to all persons residing within their territories :
( CARDINAL ) Security of person , in accordance with Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE of LAW ;
( CARDINAL ) Freedom from arbitrary arrest , detention , exile and other measures , in accordance with Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL of LAW ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the following amendment to LAW as drafted in LAW was presented by PERSON ( GPE ) :
“ LAW : add at the end :
' This provision should not exclude the right to take necessary measures to fight vagrancy and alcoholism or to ensure respect of obligations to pay a family upkeep allowance . ' ”
CARDINAL . On DATE , PERSON withdrew his amendment ,
“ provided that the statement of reasons , incorporated in the Report of ORG , stated clearly :

' ... that the text of LAW [ at this point , a general clause authorising the limitation of guaranteed rights and freedoms in order to ensure the recognition and respect of rights and liberties of others and to satisfy the requirements of morality , public order and security in a democratic society ] covers also the right of Member States to take the necessary measures to fight vagrancy and alcoholism and to ensure respect for the obligation to pay family upkeep allowance . ' ”
CARDINAL . The following commentary on LAW preliminary draft Convention was then recorded :

“ The NORP representative further requested that it be put on record that the text of Article CARDINAL covered , in particular , the right of signatory GPE to take the necessary measures for combating vagrancy and drunkenness [ l'alcoolisme in the NORP text ] or to ensure respect of obligations to pay alimony costs ; the ORG [ of Experts ] had no doubt that this could be agreed to since such restrictions were justified by the requirements of public morality and order . ”
CARDINAL . DATE , at the Second Session of the Committee of Experts , the counterpart of the present LAW was discussed and redrafted eventually as draft LAW . The following draft LAW was presented :
“ CARDINAL . No one shall be deprived of his liberty save in the following cases and in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law :
( a ) the lawful detention of a person after conviction by a competent court ;
( b ) the lawful arrest and detention of a person for non - compliance with the lawful order of a court , or in order to secure the fulfilment of any obligation prescribed by law ;

( c ) the lawful arrest or detention of a person effected for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authority on reasonable suspicion of having committed an offence or which is reasonably considered to be necessary to prevent his committing a crime , or fleeing after having done so ;
( d ) the lawful detention of minors by lawful order for the purpose of educational supervision ;
( e ) the lawful detention of persons for the prevention of the spreading of infectious diseases , of persons of unsound mind , alcoholic or drug addicts or vagrants ;
( f ) the lawful arrest or detention of a person to prevent his effecting an unauthorised entry into the country or a person against whom deportation or extradition proceedings are pending . ”
CARDINAL . At this point , the NORP version of sub - paragraph ( e ) read as follows :
“ e ) s'il s'agit de la détention régulière d'une personne susceptible de propager une maladie contagieuse , d'un aliéné , ORG alcoolique , d'un toxicomane ou d'un vagabond ; ”

CARDINAL . Finally , on CARDINAL DATE , following the last examination of the text of the Convention by ORG , the above text was replaced by the provision of the present LAW ; the changes made by ORG were described as “ formal corrections and corrections of translation ” . It was on this occasion that in the LANGUAGE text the word “ alcoholic ” in sub - paragraph ( e ) was replaced by “ alcoholics ” .
